article.p: kwebapp generates the database API in C and SQL for your web application. It accepts a configuration file that describes the business logic of your data: tables (structures), fields (members), accessors, and so forth. It then generates the source files you can include into your application. kwebapp output uses ksql(3) as a wrapper for the underlying SQLite database.

figure.figcaption: Compilation sequence from configuration to output.

article.p: Consider the following kwebapp(5) configuration file. It defines two objects, a user and a session, and establishes a relation between the session and the user. Each session, in this example, has a link to a user keyed by the userid field.

This generates the following C header file. The header file defines the C structures relating to each configured object and declares the functions necessary to acquire and release from the underlying SQLite database. Internally, the generated C code will perform the proper inner join logic on the objects.
